paragraphs: Complete Grading Rubric & Reward Point System
This system follows the principle: "Process Earns, Mastery Multiplies."
Students earn steady base points for completing daily work consistently. Bonus multipliers and thematic mastery badges reward demonstrated understanding and long-term retention.

Russian presents unique challenges: the Cyrillic alphabet, six grammatical cases, verb aspects (perfective/imperfective), and complex verbs of motion. The flashcard system includes five specialized card types and begins with explicit Cyrillic alphabet mastery before grammatical content.
Russian in Exercises is organized into two parts: Part One (Introductory Course) and Part Two (Main Course covering cases, verbs, and complex sentences). The course is divided into 10 units.
Before progressing to grammatical content, students must demonstrate mastery of the Cyrillic alphabet. This is assessed through five components in Unit 1.
33 letters: 10 vowels, 21 consonants, 2 signs (—å soft sign, —ä hard sign)
Special focus areas: Letters that look like Latin but sound different (–†=R, –ù=N, –í=V, –°=S, –£=U, –•=Kh), the soft sign —å and hard sign —ä, and the vowel reductions in unstressed syllables.
Each of the 10 units includes the following graded components:
The course grade is calculated from five categories, with speaking elevated to equal status with written work.
Flashcard Creation (all 5 types): 8% of total grade
Daily Read-Aloud: 5% of total grade (completion + self-check)
Unit Conversation Performance: 10% of total grade (rubric-based)
Weekly Speaking Assessment: 5% of total grade (cumulative rubric)
Each of the 10 unit tests: 2% of total grade
Final Exam: 12% of total grade (includes oral component)
Speaking is assessed through three complementary methods. Russian pronunciation requires particular attention to palatalization (soft consonants), stress patterns, and vowel reduction.
Records themselves reading vocabulary lists and exercise sentences
Compares their recording to native speaker reference audio
Self-assesses focusing on: stress placement, soft consonants, vowel reduction
Parent spot-checks periodically (at least 2√ó per week)
Exercise dialogues and constructed sentences are performed orally. Scored using the Speaking Rubric below.
At the end of each week, a cumulative speaking assessment combining that week's vocabulary, case forms, and grammatical structures.
Each speaking performance is scored across four categories. Maximum score = 16 points.
Stress: Russian stress is unpredictable and must be memorized for each word; unstressed vowels reduce
Palatalization: Soft consonants before –µ, —ë, –∏, —é, —è and when followed by —å
Vowel reduction: Unstressed –æ sounds like [a], unstressed –µ/—è sound like [i]
Hard vs. soft pairs: Compare –±—ã–ª [bil] vs. –±–∏–ª [b'il]
Points are earned for each completed component. These points feed directly into the reward system.
Each flashcard that reaches Leitner Box 7 earns a one-time graduation bonus. Russian uses five specialized card types.
Note: Vocabulary cards MUST include grammatical gender AND stress marking (–µ.g., –æ–∫–Ω√≥ n.) to earn full points. Cards without stress marked earn only 5 points.
Completing unit work on consecutive days earns streak multipliers applied to daily practice points.
Each unit is tagged by linguistic theme. Completing all content in a theme AND graduating all associated flashcards to Box 7 earns a Mastery Badge.
To earn a Mastery Badge (except Conversation Master), a student must:
Complete all exercises in the relevant unit(s)
Create all flashcards for that theme
Graduate ALL associated flashcards to Leitner Box 7
Score 80%+ average on unit tests covering that theme
Below is the complete mapping of all 10 units to their thematic tags.
Focus: 33 letters, print and cursive, sound-letter correspondence, reading fluency
Focus: –≤/–Ω–∞ for place, –æ/–æ–± for 'about', pronouns/adjectives in Prepositional, time expressions
Focus: Direct objects, animate vs. inanimate, verbs of motion destination, position verbs, time expressions
Focus: Recipient, –Ω—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç—å—Å—è, age expressions, impersonal sentences, prepositions –∫ and –ø–æ
Focus: Negation (–Ω–µ—Ç, –Ω–µ –±—ã–ª–æ, –Ω–µ –±—É–¥–µ—Ç), numerals, possession, comparatives, dates, prepositions –∏–∑/—Å/—É/–¥–æ/–æ–∫–æ–ª–æ
Focus: 'With' (joint action), prepositions –Ω–∞–¥/–ø–æ–¥/–ø–µ—Ä–µ–¥/–∑–∞/—Ä—è–¥–æ–º —Å, passive constructions, compound predicates
Focus: Imperfective vs. Perfective meanings, aspect pairs, usage in past/future, with –Ω–∞—á–∏–Ω–∞—Ç—å/–ø—Ä–æ–¥–æ–ª–∂–∞—Ç—å/–∑–∞–∫–∞–Ω—á–∏–≤–∞—Ç—å
Focus: 1st & 2nd conjugation, past tense, future tense, reflexive verbs (-—Å—è), participles
Focus: Conjunctions (—á—Ç–æ, –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º—É —á—Ç–æ, –µ—Å–ª–∏, —á—Ç–æ–±—ã, —Ö–æ—Ç—è, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–π), direct/indirect speech, participles, verbal adverbs
The following summarizes the maximum possible points a student can earn in Russian in Exercises.
Estimated cards per unit: ~30 vocab, ~4 case endings, ~5 conjugations, ~8 aspect pairs, ~6 motion verbs
Unit 1 Cyrillic components MUST be completed before progressing to Unit 2
Cursive is required ‚Äî Russian cursive differs significantly from print
Reading fluency should be assessed with unfamiliar words, not memorized ones
Vocabulary cards MUST include stress marking (–µ.g., –º–æ–ª–æ–∫√≥, not –º–æ–ª–æ–∫–æ)
Vocabulary cards MUST include grammatical gender (m./f./n.)
Aspect pair cards should include both members (—á–∏—Ç–∞—Ç—å/–ø—Ä–æ—á–∏—Ç–∞—Ç—å)
Verbs of motion cards should clearly indicate unidirectional vs. multidirectional
Cases are taught in order: Prepositional ‚Üí Accusative ‚Üí Dative ‚Üí Genitive ‚Üí Instrumental
Each case unit should be completed before moving to the next
Nominative case is assumed from Part One vocabulary work
Google Translate audio (acceptable for words and short phrases)
YouTube: Real Russian Club, Be Fluent in Russian for native content
tables: Cyrillic Alphabet, Nouns Singular, Present Tense (1st & 2nd Conj), Questions

–£ –º–µ–Ω—è –µ—Å—Ç—å, Demonstratives, Adjectives, Verb Aspects Intro, Verbs with -—Å—è
THE PREPOSITIONAL CASE: Place (–≤/–Ω–∞), –æ/–æ–±, Pronouns, Adjectives, Time
THE ACCUSATIVE CASE: Objects, Animate/Inanimate, Motion Verbs, Position Verbs
Midterm Exam: Part One + Prepositional + Accusative Cases
THE DATIVE CASE: Recipient, –Ω—Ä–∞–≤–∏—Ç—å—Å—è, Age, Impersonal, Prepositions –∫/–ø–æ
THE GENITIVE CASE: Negation, Numerals, Possession, Comparatives, Dates, Prep.
THE INSTRUMENTAL CASE + VERBS OF MOTION (unprefixed & prefixed)
Verbs with -—Å—è (reflexive, reciprocal, passive) + VERB ASPECTS (perf/imperf)

Write all letters correctly in print form
Write all letters in Russian cursive script
Pass Final Exam (70%+ on both written & oral)
